name: Stew of Lamb (Babylonian)
ingredients: Extra-virgin olive oil for cooking the onion
1/4 cup (50 g) rendered sheep fat or olive oil
1 lb (450 g) lamb, cut into large bite-size pieces
2 cups (475 ml) sheep milk (or goat/cow milk substitute)
1/2 cup chopped leek plus more for garnish
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F/220°C.
Mix barley flour, salt, water, and olive oil into a ragged dough. Do not knead.
Shape into thin cakes (1/4 inch) and bake for 25 minutes. Leave in cooling oven to dry.
Crush two-thirds of the cakes into crumbs and break the rest into crouton-sized pieces.
Sauté diced onion in olive oil until browned (about 7 minutes).
Melt sheep fat or olive oil in a large pot and sear the lamb with 1 tsp salt.
Add very hot water, remaining salt, and remaining fat. Simmer 5 minutes.
Add cooked onion, Persian shallot, milk, and small crumbs of risnātu.
Simmer 20 minutes.
Pound garlic into paste, then grind leek into it. Add to the stew.
Simmer covered for another 20–30 minutes until lamb is tender.
Top with risnātu croutons and garnish with chopped leek.
history: This recipe comes from the Yale Babylonian Tablets, dating to around 1740 BC. It features lamb—a prized ingredient often sourced from fat-tailed sheep, valued for their rich tail fat. The stew includes risnātu, a crunchy barley component whose exact ancient form is unknown but believed to be a dried barley cake. The book describes myths of Sheep and Grain debating their importance to humanity, showing how both ingredients played major symbolic and practical roles in Mesopotamian life. The dish likely reflects everyday Babylonian cooking with a balance of grains, dairy, aromatics, and meat.

name: Tuh’u (Babylonian Lamb & Beet Stew)
ingredients: 1 lb (450 g) leg of lamb, chopped into bite-size pieces
2–3 large red or golden beets, chopped (about 4 cups)
3/4 cup finely chopped fresh cilantro, plus more for garnish
instructions: Heat olive oil in a large pot on high heat.
Sear lamb pieces until lightly browned.
Add chopped onion and cook for 5 minutes.
Add chopped beets and cook another 5 minutes.
Pour in sour beer, arugula, cilantro, shallot, cumin, and salt. Bring to a boil.
Crush garlic into a paste, mix with chopped leek, and add to pot.
Lower heat and simmer for 60–90 minutes until meat and beets reach desired softness.
Add water gradually if stew thickens too much.
Ladle stew into bowls and sprinkle coriander seeds on top.
Garnish with fresh cilantro and Egyptian leek.
history: Tuh’u appears in the Yale Babylonian Tablets (c. 1740 BC). It is a complex lamb and beet stew that may have been served at major festivals such as the Akitu, celebrating the god Marduk’s victory over Tiamat as described in the 'Epic of Creation.' The text also reveals cultural details: lamb was expensive—costing about one shekel of silver—and ingredients like samīdu and šuhutinnū are uncertain terms in Akkadian, possibly vegetables or aromatics. The story highlights Babylonian mythology, religious ritual, and early culinary sophistication.

name: Tiger Nut Cake
ingredients: 1/2 cup (100 g) ghee or extra-virgin olive oil
instructions: Soak tiger nuts in warm water for 1 hour.
Drain and crush them with a mallet into large chunks.
Grind crushed nuts in small batches in a food processor to form coarse flour.
Mix flour with honey until combined, then add warm water gradually until a dough forms.
Heat ghee or oil in a pan over medium heat.
Toast the tiger nut dough for 4–5 minutes, stirring constantly to prevent burning.
Spread dough onto foil and let cool for about 10 minutes.
Shape the dough into a large cone laid on its side with a flat base.
Refrigerate lightly covered until firm.
Serve chilled with an optional drizzle of date syrup.
history: This recipe comes from the Tomb of Rekhmire (c. 1400 BC), where scenes depict the crushing, shaping, and preparation of tiger nut cakes. The original instructions are purely visual, leaving ingredients and method to interpretation. Tiger nuts were highly valued in Ancient Egypt—counted by officials, used in sweets, and even boiled in beer to create a naturally sweet delicacy, as noted by Theophrastus. Though the exact ancient recipe is unknown, the book recreates a plausible version consistent with the depictions on Rekhmire’s tomb walls.

name: Epityrum (Roman Olive Relish)
ingredients: 1/4 cup (60 ml) extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for drizzling
2 cups (300 g) pitted green and black olives
Mild goat cheese and bread (for serving)
instructions: Mix cilantro, fennel, mint, rue, and cumin in a small bowl.
Add vinegar and olive oil and mix well to form the dressing.
Rinse olives lightly under cool water and pat dry.
Finely chop or mash olives into desired texture.
Combine olives with the herb mixture and mix well.
Cover and let marinate overnight or for several days for deeper flavor.
Serve with bread and mild goat cheese, drizzled with olive oil.
history: Epityrum is described by Cato the Elder in *De Agri Cultura* as a seasoned olive relish combining green, black, and mottled olives with herbs, oil, and vinegar. Olives were central to Roman and Greek cuisine, but this preparation highlights the fruit itself rather than just the oil. According to Greek mythology, olives were a gift from the goddess Athena, whose tree grew atop the Acropolis. They were considered sacred, and harming an olive tree could lead to trial. The story of Athena’s olive defeating Poseidon's saltwater spring symbolizes wisdom prevailing over brute force—an appropriate context for this refined yet simple relish.

name: Kykeon (Ancient Greek Ritual Drink)
instructions: Toast hulled barley in a dry pan over medium heat until aromatic (7–10 minutes).
Coarsely grind toasted barley in a mortar and pestle.
Boil ground barley in water for 60–90 minutes until soft like porridge.
Drain excess water.
Place barley porridge into a bowl or cup and add red wine until drinkable.
Add a spoonful of honey and mix.
Grate aged goat cheese on top and serve.
history: Kykeon appears throughout classical Greek literature, including Homer’s Odyssey and Iliad. It was used as a magical or ritual potion—famously by the witch Circe, who mixed it with drugs to transform Odysseus’s men into pigs. In the Eleusinian Mysteries, initiates consumed kykeon after fasting, possibly with psychoactive herbs, to commune with the gods Demeter and Persephone. A later example in the Iliad shows kykeon being used medicinally, mixed with onion relish and goat's cheese. Though Pramnian wine (the original ingredient) is no longer available, the recreation uses a dry red wine to approximate ancient flavor.

name: Melas Zomos (Spartan Black Broth)
ingredients: 4 tbsp (60 ml) extra-virgin olive oil, divided
2 lbs (900 g) pork shoulder, cut into 1-inch squares
instructions: Heat 2 tablespoons of olive oil in a skillet over medium-high heat and cook the onion until browned (about 10 minutes).
Heat remaining olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat and add pork pieces.
Season with salt and pepper, browning the pork on all sides (about 3 minutes).
Add cooked onion, bay leaves, water, and vinegar. Bring to a boil over high heat.
Reduce heat and simmer covered for 45 minutes until pork is tender.
Prepare pork blood by blending with 1 cup water if coagulated, then straining.
Add liquified pork blood to the soup and simmer for at least 15 minutes.
Serve hot.
history: Melas Zomos, the infamous Spartan Black Broth, is described by ancient writers Plutarch and Athenaeus as the daily staple of Spartan warriors. This dark soup was made from pork, its blood, and vinegar. It was served at the communal military mess halls, the syssitia, where Spartans ate simple, austere meals. Outsiders often mocked the broth—Athenaeus recounts a Sybarite who tasted it and claimed it explained why Spartans were unafraid of death. Despite its reputation, the dish reflects Spartan values: discipline, equality among warriors, and a rejection of luxury. Its stark simplicity symbolized the harsh training and lifestyle of the Spartan people.

name: Globi (Roman Cheese & Spelt Honey Balls)
ingredients: 1 cup + 1 tbsp (120 g) spelt, durum, or other whole-grain flour
1 quart (1 liter) extra-virgin olive oil (for frying)
instructions: Mix flour, ricotta, and salt until well combined.
Form dough into 1-inch balls (about 20–24).
Heat olive oil in a saucepan to 325°F (165°C).
Lower heat to medium and fry 2–3 balls at a time, turning every 10–15 seconds.
Fry until golden brown (60–90 seconds).
Drain on a wire rack over paper towels.
Dip warm globi in honey (heat honey if too thick).
Sprinkle or coat with poppy seeds and serve warm.
history: Globi is described by Cato the Elder in *De Agri Cultura* as small fried cheese-and-grain balls dipped in honey and sprinkled with poppy seeds. In Ancient Rome, these sweet treats were commonly associated with Saturnalia—a December festival where social norms relaxed, gambling was allowed, and slaves could dine with masters. Gifts were exchanged, including small figurines called sigillaria. Writers like Martial and Suetonius noted the festive chaos and comedic gift-giving at Saturnalia. Globi fit perfectly into the celebratory, indulgent atmosphere and may be one of the earliest examples of bite-sized dessert confections in Western culinary history.

name: Placenta (Roman Layered Honey–Cheese Cake)
ingredients: 2/3 cup (120 g) whole spelt or emmer
3/4 cup (255 g) honey, plus more for coating
12–15 fresh bay leaves coated in olive oil
instructions: Grind whole spelt or emmer coarsely using a mortar.
Place ground grain in a bowl with 1 cup water and soak for 24 hours.
Mix soaked grain and remaining water with flour to form a dough.
Knead until smooth, divide into six pieces, and rest 20 minutes.
Roll each piece into an 8-inch thin disc (tracta). Let dry 4–6 hours until leathery.
Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C).
Rinse feta cheese to remove excess salt, repeating up to three times if needed.
Press cheese until smooth, then mix in honey to form filling.
Make crust by mixing 3/4 cup water with 1.5 cups flour, knead 5 minutes, and rest 20 minutes.
Roll crust dough into a large thin disc.
Line a 9-inch baking dish with oiled bay leaves, then place crust on top, allowing edges to hang over.
Brush first tracta with olive oil and place on crust. Spread 1/3 of cheese–honey filling.
Layer another oiled tracta and repeat until filling is used, ending with the fourth tracta.
Fold crust over the top to encase the layers.
Cover with lid and bake 1 hour 10 minutes, then uncover and bake 10 minutes more.
Remove from dish and drizzle generously with honey. Serve warm.
history: Placenta is a layered honey-and-cheese cake described in detail by Cato the Elder in *De Agri Cultura*. The dish consists of layered tracta (thin sheets of dough) alternated with a rich filling of sheep’s cheese and honey, encased in a crust. Its name, meaning 'flat cake', is the origin of the modern anatomical term, though the food came first. Cato, a staunch traditionalist, promoted Roman farming values and recorded this recipe as part of broader agricultural instruction. The dish’s complexity suggests it was a prestigious offering, reflecting both rural Roman traditions and the influence of earlier Greek layered pastries.

name: Puls (Roman Gladiator Barley & Fava Bean Porridge)
ingredients: 2 tsp garum or Asian fish sauce
instructions: Soak dried fava beans and barley in separate bowls for 12 hours.
Drain and peel the fava beans.
Heat olive oil in a pot and cook chopped onion until translucent (about 5 minutes).
Add 1 quart of water and bring to a boil.
Add barley, cover, and boil for 30 minutes.
Add peeled fava beans, garlic, vinegar, and garum.
Simmer uncovered for 30 minutes until thick porridge consistency forms.
Serve warm.
history: Puls was the foundational staple of the Roman diet and particularly associated with gladiators. Galen, physician to the fighters of Pergamon, describes a barley-and-bean porridge that produced soft, heavy flesh rather than lean muscle—useful as natural padding against cuts in combat. Juvenal referred to this dish as the 'hotchpotch of the gladiator,' emphasizing its humble, filling nature. Gladiators were even nicknamed *hordearii*, meaning 'barley men,' underscoring how central grains were to their diet. This simple porridge reflects the everyday fuel of Rome’s fighters and the practicality of ancient nutrition.

name: In Mitulis (Roman Mussels)
ingredients: 2 tbsp (30 ml) Vin Santo or fortified sweet wine
1 tbsp (15 ml) garum or other fish sauce
1/2 tsp dried or 1.5 tsp minced fresh savory
instructions: Wash mussels under running water and discard any that remain open or damaged.
Place chopped leek in a large pot.
Add water, white wine, sweet wine, garum, cumin, and savory.
Mix well, then add mussels on top.
Cover the pot and cook on high heat for 5–7 minutes until mussels open.
Discard any mussels that did not open.
Serve immediately with broth.
history: This recipe comes from *Apicius – De Re Coquinaria*, the primary surviving Roman cookbook. Apicius, Rome’s most famous gourmand, was known for extravagant feasts featuring rare ingredients like flamingo tongues and drunken figs. Though many Apician recipes are elaborate, In Mitulis is surprisingly simple, relying on garum, wine, leek, and savory to create a flavorful broth. The book recounts Apicius’s extreme devotion to culinary luxury—sailing to Libya in search of larger shrimp, convincing nobles to avoid certain vegetables, and ultimately taking his life when he believed his remaining wealth was insufficient for proper dining. Despite the legend, this mussel recipe reflects the more practical, everyday side of Roman seafood cooking.

name: Patina de Piris (Patina of Pears)
instructions: Boil the pears until soft, then peel, core, and mash them.
Transfer mashed pears to a bowl and add pepper, cumin, honey, passum, garum, and olive oil. Mix well.
Beat the eggs in a separate bowl.
Stir beaten eggs into the pear mixture until fully combined.
Pour mixture into a greased baking dish.
Bake at 350°F (175°C) for 30–40 minutes, until set.
Sprinkle with black pepper before serving.
history: This recipe appears in the ancient Roman cookbook *Apicius – De re coquinaria*. It describes a sweet patina (a layered or baked dish) combining boiled pears with honey, cumin, pepper, passum, garum, and eggs. Although sweet, Roman desserts often featured spices and even savory elements such as garum. Pears were a common fruit in the empire and frequently paired with wine and honey. Roman cookery embraced combining sweet and savory flavors, and this dish is essentially a sweetened fruit frittata—a far cry from the modern idea of dessert but very typical of ancient Roman taste.

name: Vitellian Piglet (Roman Suckling Pig)
ingredients: 1 (3- to 4-pound / 1.5 kg) whole piglet or small roasting pig
3 tbsp (45 ml) garum or Asian fish sauce
1 tbsp dried lovage or celery leaf (2 tbsp if using fresh leaves)
1½ tsp freshly ground black pepper, plus extra for garnish
instructions: Preheat the oven to 450°F (230°C).
Quarter the piglet and place pieces in a single layer in an oven-safe dish. (Optional: refrigerate overnight for crispier skin.)
Mix wine and garum in a bowl. Add lovage, black pepper, and caraway seeds. Pour this marinade over the piglet, rubbing to coat.
Mix asafetida with lukewarm water and pour evenly over the piglet.
Roast on the middle oven rack for 40–45 minutes or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
Let the piglet rest in the dish for 10 minutes. Serve with pan sauce and garnish with black pepper.
history: Vitellian Piglet is connected to the infamous Roman emperor Vitellius, known for his gluttony and extravagant feasts during AD 69. Roman historians like Cassius Dio recount that Vitellius ordered lavish dishes featuring rare animals, exotic seafood, and entire organs of beasts. Although we cannot be certain that this specific piglet recipe was his invention, the seasoning—wine, garum, lovage, caraway, and asafetida—matches flavor profiles in Apicius. The dish reflects the excess of Vitellius's short rule and the Roman love for richly seasoned roasted meats.

name: Pullum Parthicum (Parthian Chicken)
ingredients: 3 tbsp (45 ml) garum or Asian fish sauce
1 tbsp dried lovage or celery leaf (2 tbsp if fresh)
1½ tsp freshly ground black pepper, plus extra for garnish
instructions: Preheat oven to 450°F (230°C).
Quarter the chicken and place in a single layer in an oven-safe dish.
Mix red wine, garum, lovage, pepper, and caraway in a bowl.
Pour mixture over chicken, coating well.
Dissolve asafetida in lukewarm water and pour over chicken.
Roast for 40–45 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 165°F (74°C).
Rest for 10 minutes, then serve with the pan sauce and extra pepper.
history: Pullum Parthicum is a Roman dish from *Apicius – De re coquinaria*, named after the Parthian Empire. The original text instructs cooks to season chicken with pepper, lovage, caraway, wine, garum, and dissolved silphium. Since true silphium became extinct in the first century, Romans used asafetida as a substitute—an ingredient still used today in Indian cuisine. The Parthian Empire controlled the Silk Road, acting as middlemen between Rome and China, and their cuisine influenced Roman tastes. This dish reflects that cultural and culinary exchange, blending Roman techniques with Eastern flavors.

name: Sauce with Herbs for Fried Fish
ingredients: Silphium root (or powdered asafetida as replacement)
instructions: Pound pepper, cumin, coriander seed, silphium root (or asafetida), oregano, and rue into a paste.
Moisten the herb mixture with vinegar.
Add dates, honey, defrutum, olive oil, and garum.
Mix all ingredients in a pot and bring to a gentle boil.
Once boiling, remove from heat.
Pour the hot sauce over freshly fried fish.
Sprinkle with pepper before serving.
history: This recipe comes from *Apicius – De re coquinaria*, which describes a sweet, aromatic sauce meant for fried fish. Its defining ingredient was silphium—a treasured resin from Cyrene that was so rare and valued that the Romans stocked it in their treasury alongside silver. Pliny the Elder writes that silphium went extinct when Emperor Nero consumed the last stalk. Asafetida, imported from the Parthian Empire, became the accepted replacement. The sauce combines spices, herbs, honey, dates, defrutum, and garum to create a complex flavor that Apicius considered suitable not only for fish but for many dishes. The book explains the cultural fascination with silphium, its medicinal uses, and how its extinction forced Romans to adapt their recipes.

name: Hippocras (Medieval Spiced Wine)
ingredients: 1 tsp ground grains of paradise (or black pepper)
instructions: Pour red wine into a large jug or bowl.
Add sugar, cinnamon, ginger, grains of paradise (or pepper), and cloves.
Whisk or stir well until sugar dissolves.
Cover and allow the mixture to infuse for at least 3 hours, or overnight for stronger flavor.
Strain the wine through fine cloth or a coffee filter until clear.
Serve chilled or at room temperature.
history: Hippocras was a prized medieval delicacy: sweetened, spiced wine filtered until perfectly clear. It appears in numerous medieval manuscripts and was often served at feasts, weddings, and royal banquets. The name comes from the 'Hippocratic sleeve,' a conical cloth filter supposedly inspired by Hippocrates. Medieval physicians considered Hippocras a digestive aid and a symbol of refinement. It also reflects the spice trade routes of the Middle Ages—cinnamon, ginger, cloves, grains of paradise, and sugar were expensive luxury imports that demonstrated wealth when served at courtly meals.

name: Dillegrout (Bardolf)
ingredients: 1½ lbs (680 g) skinless capon or chicken thighs
¼ cup (50 g) dark brown sugar
½ tsp dried chopped ginger or ground ginger
⅛ cup (30 ml) white wine vinegar
instructions: Soak the almonds in cool water for 2 hours, then drain.
Place soaked almonds and wine in a saucepan. Add chicken breast and chicken thighs.
Simmer gently for 90 minutes until meat is fully cooked.
Remove chicken pieces and shred them finely.
Strain almonds from the wine and press to extract liquid. Discard solids.
Return almond-wine broth to pan. Add sugar, clove, mace, pine nuts, ginger, and salt.
Add shredded chicken into the broth.
Simmer for 45 minutes until thickened.
Stir in vinegar and rosewater just before removing from heat.
Serve warm as a thick medieval pottage.
history: Dillegrout (also Bardolf) was a ceremonial Anglo-Norman dish prepared for English coronations starting with Matilda of Flanders in 1068. The right and duty to cook it was granted to Tezelin, the royal cook, along with the manor of Addington. Whoever held the manor was obligated to prepare this spiced chicken-almond stew at every coronation for over seven centuries. The only surviving recipe appears in the Arundel Manuscript and describes a rich pottage of almond milk, wine, capon, pine nuts, ginger, cloves, and sugar. Its repeated appearance at coronations makes it one of England’s oldest continuously prepared ceremonial dishes.

name: Douce Ame (Capon in Milk & Honey)
ingredients: Good cow’s milk (enough to simmer chicken pieces)
1 whole capon (or chicken), half roasted and cut into pieces
instructions: Warm cow’s milk gently in a pot.
Chop parsley, sage, hyssop, savory, and other herbs; add to the milk and simmer.
Add the half-roasted, cut capon pieces into the herb-infused milk.
Stir in pine nuts and clarified honey.
Season with salt and add saffron to color the dish a golden hue.
Simmer until the sauce thickens and the chicken is fully cooked.
Serve warm with extra sauce.
history: Douce Ame is a sweet, herb-filled chicken dish from the 14th-century English cookbook *The Forme of Cury*. It was originally prepared using capon, a castrated rooster prized for its tender meat. Medieval writers—including Bartholomaeus Anglicus—describe capons as luxury birds associated with affluent households. The dish combines milk, honey, herbs, and saffron, reflecting the medieval preference for sweet-savory blends. Douce Ame appears often in manuscripts, indicating its popularity among wealthy families and clergy. Writers like Chaucer and Shakespeare mention capons frequently, associating them with indulgence, prosperity, and festive meals.

name: Shrove Tuesday Pancakes
instructions: Whisk together flour, eggs, milk, ale, and melted butter until smooth.
Heat butter or oil in a skillet over medium heat.
Pour a small amount of batter into the pan, tilting to create a thin layer.
Cook until the edges crisp and the bottom browns, then flip.
Cook the other side until lightly golden.
Repeat with the remaining batter.
Serve sprinkled with sugar and a squeeze of lemon.
history: Shrove Tuesday Pancakes originate from the medieval English tradition of using up rich ingredients before Lent. The word 'shrive' means to confess, reflecting the religious practice of preparing spiritually for fasting. Pancakes were an ideal way to use leftover eggs, dairy, and fats. The book notes that Shrovetide customs included rowdy festivities such as pancake races, football, and feasting. By the Tudor period, pancakes had become symbolic of the day, with cookbooks describing light, thin cakes flavored with ale and fried in butter. The tradition continues today across the UK as 'Pancake Day.'

name: Pumpion Pie (Pumpkin Pie, 1670)
ingredients: Lard or vegetable oil, for frying
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Cut the top stem off the pumpkin, halve it, remove peel and seeds, and slice into thin 1/8-inch slices.
Peel and core apples, then slice thinly.
Mix rosemary, parsley, and thyme with beaten eggs.
Dip pumpkin slices into the egg-herb mixture to coat.
Heat 1/4 inch of oil in a skillet and fry pumpkin slices until soft, 5–7 minutes per side. Drain on a wire rack.
Repeat frying in batches, discarding burnt egg bits as needed.
Transfer all fried pumpkin into a bowl. Add 2 tablespoons butter, raisins, currants, sugar, and sherry; mix well.
Line the bottom of the pie crust with apple slices.
Pour the pumpkin mixture over apples and smooth the top.
Bake 20 minutes at 425°F, then reduce heat to 375°F (190°C) and bake 40–50 minutes until bubbling.
Remove from oven and dot the remaining 2 tablespoons butter over the top to melt.
Cool completely before slicing.
history: This 1670 recipe comes from Hannah Woolley’s 'The Queen-like Closet; or, Rich Cabinet.' Woolley was one of the first women in history to earn a living as a professional writer. Early English pumpkin pies were not creamy custards like modern American pies. Instead, thin fried pumpkin slices were layered with apples, herbs, raisins, currants, sugar, and sherry before being baked inside a crust. The recipe reflects how new pumpkins were to Europe—they had not yet added the letter 'k' to 'pumpion.' The book explains how pumpkin pie later became associated with American Thanksgiving, though it was not present at the first 1621 feast.

name: Everlasting Syllabub
ingredients: 1/2 pint (approx. 236 ml) sack (or sweet white wine)
Juice of 2 Seville oranges or lemons
1 pound (450 g) double-refined sugar, beaten and sifted
instructions: Combine thick cream with sack (or white wine) in a large bowl.
Add lemon or Seville orange juice and the grated lemon zest.
Add the sifted sugar and orange-flower water.
Whisk the mixture vigorously for 30 minutes until it thickens and becomes airy.
Spoon into glasses and allow to stand so the foam remains on top.
Serve chilled.
history: This recipe comes from Hannah Glasse’s 1747 classic 'The Art of Cookery Made Plain and Easy.' Early syllabub began as a drink in which wine curdled cream, creating a foamy top layer that diners sipped over liquor. By the 17th century, it evolved into a dessert featuring whipped, sweetened cream stabilized with wine or citrus. In Georgian England, Everlasting Syllabub was a fashionable dessert served at aristocratic suppers and parties. The name comes from its long-lasting foam, created by extensive whisking and the stabilizing effect of wine and citrus.

name: Potage d’Onions au Lait (Onion Soup with Milk)
instructions: Melt the butter in a pot over medium heat.
Add sliced onions and cook until very soft but not browned, about 20–25 minutes.
Pour in the milk and bring just to a simmer.
Season with salt and black pepper.
Simmer gently for 10–15 minutes.
Serve hot with toasted bread or croutons.
history: This recipe comes from 18th-century French cooking and appears in the same chapter as Everlasting Syllabub. Onion soups had been common since medieval times, but Potage d’Onions au Lait was a simpler, humbler version meant for everyday families rather than taverns. Milk-based soups were common in rural French households, where milk was more plentiful than meat broth. The book notes that this dish predates the famous gratinéed French onion soup of Parisian restaurants and represents an earlier, comforting farmhouse tradition.

name: Chard Casserole (Pottage of Greens)
ingredients: 1 pound (450 g) Swiss chard or mixed greens
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F/175°C.
Wash the chard thoroughly and chop into small pieces.
Boil the greens in salted water until tender, about 10 minutes, then drain well.
In a bowl, whisk together milk, eggs, salt, pepper, and nutmeg.
Butter a baking dish and spread the cooked greens evenly across the bottom.
Pour the milk-and-egg mixture over the greens.
Dot the top with butter.
Bake for 30–35 minutes, until set and lightly golden.
history: This medieval French greens casserole comes from Le Ménagier de Paris, a 14th-century household guide written for a young bride by her older husband. Greens like chard, beet tops, and spinach were common staples for poorer households who relied on easily grown vegetables. Though simple, this pottage-style casserole reflects medieval culinary principles—using eggs and dairy to enrich otherwise modest ingredients.

name: Cannetons de Roüen à l’échalote (Rouen Duck with Shallots)
instructions: Preheat oven to 425°F (220°C).
Season the duck generously with salt and pepper.
Place duck breast-side up in a roasting pan and roast for 45 to 55 minutes until cooked through.
Remove the duck from the pan and set aside to rest.
Pour off excess fat from the pan, leaving the browned drippings.
Add minced shallots into the pan and cook until soft.
Pour in red wine and bring to a simmer, scraping the pan to lift browned bits.
Cook until the sauce reduces by about half.
Whisk in butter to create a glossy finish.
Carve the duck and serve with the shallot-wine sauce.
history: Rouen-style duck comes from northern France and traditionally used a special breed called the Canard de Rouen, prized for its rich flavor. The recipe in the book notes that this early version from 19th-century French cuisine predates the more elaborate pressed-duck method served at Paris’s La Tour d’Argent. This simplified version with a reduced shallot-red wine sauce reflects Normandy’s culinary heritage, where shallots and wine were key staples.

name: Semlor (Hettwägg med mandel)
instructions: Slice a round lid off the top of each bun.
Scoop out the inside of each bun and place it in a bowl.
Soak the removed bread in sweet cream or milk until soft.
Add one egg per bun to the soaked bread mixture.
Add crushed almonds, sugar, melted butter, and a little salt. Mix well.
Heat the mixture over gentle heat until thickened but not solidified.
Fill the hollowed buns with the warm almond mixture and place the lids back on.
Tie each bun with thick string to hold the lids in place.
Place the filled buns upright in a wide pot.
Pour milk into the pot (not enough to fully submerge the buns).
Boil for 30 minutes.
In a separate pot, boil sweet milk with sugar and butter.
Thicken the milk slightly by whisking in two egg yolks.
Remove string, place buns in a deep dish, pour a little of the milk mixture over them, and serve the rest on the side.
history: This 1755 recipe appears in Cajsa Warg’s Swedish household manual 'Hjelpreda i hushållningen för unga fruentimber.' These early semlor, called hettwägg, were eaten on Fat Tuesday. Unlike modern semlor filled with almond paste and whipped cream, this older version boiled the almond-filled buns in milk. The dish became infamous as the last meal of King Adolf Frederick of Sweden, who reportedly died after eating fourteen servings, though it was likely another health issue that killed him.

name: Pomodori Farciti all’Erbette (Stuffed Tomatoes with Herbs)
instructions: Preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C).
Cut the tops off the tomatoes and scoop out the pulp.
Season the insides lightly with salt.
Mix parsley, basil, mint, and breadcrumbs with olive oil to form a loose stuffing.
Fill each tomato with the herb–breadcrumb mixture.
Drizzle olive oil on top and season with pepper.
Place tomatoes in a baking dish and bake for 20–25 minutes until tender.
history: This 18th-century Northern Italian recipe showcases how tomatoes, once considered exotic, became fully integrated into Italian cooking. Early European tomato dishes often emphasized herbs and breadcrumbs rather than cheese or meat. The simplicity of the preparation reflects regional Mediterranean cooking, where fresh herbs and olive oil define flavor. The book notes that stuffed vegetables like these became popular across Italy in the 1700s as tomatoes gained acceptance both in gardens and kitchens.

name: Poutine Râpée (Acadian Pork-Dumpling Stew)
ingredients: 1½ lbs (680 g) pork (preferably fatty cuts like shoulder)
instructions: Season pork generously with salt and pepper.
Simmer pork in water for 1 to 1½ hours until tender. Remove meat; save broth.
Shred pork into small pieces.
Peel and grate all russet potatoes.
Place grated potatoes in a strainer and press to remove liquid.
Let the extracted potato liquid sit until starch settles at the bottom; pour off the water and reserve starch.
Mix grated potatoes with reserved starch and some salt to form a thick dough.
Shape dough into large balls and fill each with a spoonful of shredded pork.
Pinch dough to seal completely around the pork.
Bring the reserved pork broth (plus extra water if needed) to a gentle boil.
Add dumplings and simmer for 2 to 3 hours until dumplings become translucent.
Serve hot, traditionally with brown sugar or molasses.
history: Poutine râpée is a traditional Acadian dish dating back to the 17th–18th centuries. It consists of grated potato dumplings filled with salted pork and simmered for hours until translucent. The dish survived the Great Expulsion of the Acadians in 1755, when thousands were forcibly relocated by the British. Despite hardship, the recipe endured because it uses inexpensive staples—potatoes and pork—and yields a hearty meal capable of feeding large families. Today it is deeply tied to Acadian identity and is especially eaten during holidays in New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and Prince Edward Island.

name: Tourtière (Québécois Meat Pie)
ingredients: 2 medium russet potatoes, peeled and finely diced
Pie crust for a 9-inch double-crust pie
instructions: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
In a large pot, combine ground pork, beef, veal, and onion.
Add beef broth, salt, cinnamon, cloves, allspice, and nutmeg.
Bring to a simmer and cook uncovered for 25 minutes, stirring often.
Add diced potatoes and continue cooking 15 minutes until mixture thickens.
Remove from heat and cool slightly.
Line a 9-inch pie pan with bottom crust and fill with meat mixture.
Place top crust over filling, seal edges, and cut small vents.
Bake for 35–40 minutes until golden brown.
Let rest 10 minutes before slicing.
history: Tourtière is a traditional meat pie from Quebec, commonly served on Christmas Eve (Réveillon). Recipes vary widely—some use only pork, while others use mixtures of pork, beef, veal, or even game. This version reflects the 19th-century Quebec household style documented in regional Canadian cookbooks. The spice blend of cinnamon, cloves, allspice, and nutmeg shows strong French influence. The dish became a holiday staple after the British conquest of New France, as meat pies aligned well with wintertime, communal feasting, and the province’s agricultural traditions.

name: Birch Syrup Butter Tart
instructions: Preheat the oven to 425°F (220°C).
Arrange the unbaked tart shells on a parchment-lined baking sheet.
In a bowl, combine melted butter, granulated sugar, and brown sugar.
Stir in the beaten egg, birch syrup, vanilla extract, vinegar, and salt.
Mix until smooth.
Divide the filling evenly among the tart shells, filling each about two-thirds full.
Bake for 12 to 15 minutes until the filling is bubbling and the crust is golden brown.
Cool on a wire rack before serving.
history: Butter tarts are a quintessential Canadian dessert, believed to have been created in the early 20th century, though they likely evolved from Scottish and English custard and treacle tarts. This Yukon variation replaces corn syrup with birch syrup, a local specialty produced from the sap of birch trees. Birch syrup is far more complex and less sweet than maple syrup, giving the butter tart a deep, molasses-like flavor. The book notes that birch syrup production is labor-intensive—requiring roughly 100 liters of sap to make 1 liter of syrup—and therefore it remains a prized northern delicacy.

name: Sourdough Biscuits
ingredients: 1 tablespoon (14 g) lard or softened butter
instructions: Preheat the oven to 450°F (230°C).
Mix the sourdough starter and milk in a large bowl.
Add flour, salt, and baking soda; stir until a soft dough forms.
Turn out the dough on a floured surface and knead lightly.
Roll dough to ¾-inch thickness.
Cut biscuits using a round cutter or the rim of a tin cup.
Place biscuits in a greased cast-iron skillet touching each other.
Top each biscuit with a bit of lard or butter.
Bake 12–15 minutes until golden brown.
history: Sourdough biscuits were a staple of American frontier cooking. Cowboys, prospectors, and loggers relied on sourdough starter because commercial yeast was unavailable on the trail. Starters were passed down like family heirlooms, kept alive for years. The book notes that sourdough was so essential that miners during the Klondike Gold Rush were nicknamed 'sourdoughs.' Biscuits like these were cooked in cast-iron Dutch ovens over open fires and served with beans, stews, or strong coffee.

name: Boston Brown Bread
instructions: Grease a 4-cup heatproof mold or empty coffee can.
Whisk together rye flour, whole wheat flour, cornmeal, baking soda, and salt.
In another bowl, whisk buttermilk, whole milk, and molasses.
Combine wet and dry ingredients; fold in raisins if using.
Pour batter into the prepared mold and cover tightly with foil.
Place the mold in a large pot. Add hot water halfway up the sides.
Cover the pot and steam over medium-low heat for 2 hours.
Remove the mold and cool for 10 minutes before unmolding.
Slice and serve warm, traditionally with baked beans.
history: Boston Brown Bread is a classic New England dish dating back to the 18th and 19th centuries, when wheat flour was scarce and expensive. New England cooks created this dense, sweet steamed bread using rye, wheat, and cornmeal—grains local farmers could grow easily. The book notes that steaming rather than baking was a regional hallmark, especially in homes without large ovens. Paired with Saturday-night baked beans, brown bread became a cultural symbol of frugal Yankee cooking rooted in practicality and local harvests.

name: Election Cake
instructions: Warm the milk and dissolve the yeast in it.
Add 1 cup of flour to make a sponge. Cover and let rise for 1 hour.
In another bowl, cream butter and sugar until smooth.
Beat in eggs, salt, and all spices.
Add remaining flour to form a soft dough.
Mix the risen sponge into the dough and knead well.
Fold in raisins and brandy (if using).
Place dough in a greased bundt or loaf pan and let rise 1 to 2 hours.
Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C).
Bake for 40–45 minutes until golden brown.
Cool before slicing.
history: Election Cake originated in colonial New England and was traditionally baked for state and federal election days. Before the Revolutionary War, large town gatherings required substantial food to feed voters who might travel long distances. The first recorded recipe appeared in Amelia Simmons’s 1796 'American Cookery,' and called for large quantities of flour, butter, eggs, and spices—often baked in communal ovens. The book explains that the cake symbolized civic duty and celebration, long before modern polling stations existed. Spiced and yeast-raised, it represents one of the earliest uniquely American baked traditions.

name: Oyster Ice Cream
instructions: Shuck the oysters, reserving their liquor.
Finely mince the oyster meat.
Combine cream and milk in a saucepan and warm over medium heat.
In a bowl, whisk egg yolks and sugar until pale and thick.
Slowly pour the warm milk mixture into the yolks while whisking.
Return mixture to the saucepan and cook until it thickens into a custard, about 10 minutes.
Add minced oysters, oyster liquor, and salt.
Simmer gently for 5 minutes, then remove from heat.
Strain to remove solids if a smoother texture is desired.
Chill custard completely, then freeze in an ice-cream maker.
history: Oyster ice cream appeared during the Victorian era in America, when oysters were extremely popular and used in everything from stews to pies. The book notes that this ice cream likely began as a savory frozen dish served at elaborate banquets in the mid-1800s. Oysters were seen as luxurious but accessible, and freezing savory foods was a culinary trend of the time. Recipes for oyster ice cream appear in 19th-century catering menus and cookbooks, often served alongside other unusual flavors such as parmesan and artichoke ice cream.

name: Sea Biscuits (Hardtack)
ingredients: 1 cup (235 ml) water, or as needed
instructions: Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C).
Mix flour and salt in a bowl.
Add water gradually, stirring until a stiff dough forms.
Knead briefly until smooth.
Roll out to 1/2-inch thickness.
Cut into squares or rectangles.
Prick each biscuit several times with a fork to allow drying.
Place on an ungreased baking sheet.
Bake 45–60 minutes until dried and very firm.
Cool completely before storing.
history: Hardtack—called 'sea biscuits' or 'ship biscuits'—was the primary ration for sailors for centuries. The book explains that these biscuits were baked multiple times to remove moisture so they could last months or even years during sea voyages. They were notoriously hard and often needed to be soaked in water, coffee, or soup. The British Royal Navy and American sailors relied on them heavily, and during the Age of Sail, a ship's entire food supply revolved around hardtack, salt pork, and dried peas. Weevils infesting hardtack was a common problem, leading sailors to dunk the biscuits to float the bugs out.

name: Mango Chutney (Anglo-Indian)
ingredients: 6 large unripe (green) mangoes, peeled and diced
instructions: Combine diced mangoes, sugar, and vinegar in a large pot.
Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer.
Stir in salt, ginger, turmeric, mustard, and red pepper flakes.
Add chopped raisins and mix well.
Simmer uncovered for 45–60 minutes until thickened, stirring occasionally.
Cool completely before storing in jars.
Refrigerate for best flavor.
history: Mango chutney originated in India but became globally popular through the Anglo-Indian kitchens of the British Raj. In the 1800s, British colonials adapted Indian preservation techniques using vinegar and sugar to create long-lasting chutneys that could be shipped back to Britain. The book explains that mango chutney represented a merging of Indian ingredients with European preserving traditions. By the Victorian era, commercially bottled mango chutney had become a staple in British households and appeared frequently alongside curries.

name: Khichuri (Bengal)
ingredients: 3 tablespoons (42 g) ghee or vegetable oil
instructions: Rinse rice and lentils thoroughly until water runs clear.
Heat ghee or oil in a pot over medium heat.
Add cumin seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds.
Stir in turmeric and salt.
Add the rice and lentils; stir to coat with the spices.
Pour in the water and bring to a boil.
Add optional vegetables if using.
Reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer 30–40 minutes until soft and porridge-like.
Adjust consistency with more water if desired.
Serve warm.
history: Khichuri is one of Bengal’s oldest comfort foods, combining rice and lentils into a warming, porridge-like dish. Historically, it was eaten during monsoons and offered during pujas. British colonials encountered it in the 18th century and adapted it into 'kedgeree,' adding fish and eggs. The book highlights that khichuri appears in numerous Bengali manuscripts and was favored for its simplicity, nutrition, and adaptability with vegetables. It remains a staple across India today, symbolizing warmth, comfort, and home cooking.

name: Mango Fool (18th-Century Britain)
instructions: Purée the diced mangoes with sugar and lemon juice until smooth.
Whip the heavy cream with vanilla extract until soft peaks form.
Fold the whipped cream gently into the mango purée.
Chill for at least 1 hour before serving.
Spoon into cups or bowls and serve cold.
history: Fruit 'fools' were popular British desserts as early as the 1600s, traditionally made by folding puréed fruit into sweetened cream. While gooseberry fool was the most common, the 18th century saw the introduction of exotic fruits like mangoes through colonial trade. The book notes that mango fool became a fashionable dish among wealthy Georgian households who could afford imported tropical produce. Simple, luxurious, and lightly sweet, it reflects Britain's growing fascination with global flavors during the age of empire.

name: Syllabub Trifle (Georgian / Regency England)
ingredients: 1 loaf sponge cake or several ladyfingers
1/2 cup (120 ml) sweet wine or sherry
instructions: Slice sponge cake or arrange ladyfingers in the bottom of a trifle dish.
Sprinkle sweet wine or sherry (and brandy, if using) over the cake to soak.
Whisk sugar, lemon juice, lemon zest, cream, and milk together.
Whip the mixture until lightly thickened and frothy, similar to traditional syllabub consistency.
Pour the syllabub mixture gently over the soaked cake.
Grate nutmeg over the top.
Chill several hours or overnight before serving.
history: This dessert blends two beloved Georgian dishes: trifle and syllabub. Syllabub—made by whisking cream with wine, sugar, and citrus—was popular from the 1600s onward. Trifle, originally a simple cream dessert, evolved in the 18th century into elaborate layered creations of cake, spirits, custard, and whipped creams. By the Regency era, cooks combined these traditions, topping soaked cake with a frothy syllabub mixture. The book notes that this version was fashionable in upper-class households and often served at evening suppers.

name: Fire-Roasted Corn with Chili–Lime Butter
instructions: Prepare a grill or open flame over medium-high heat.
Place corn directly over the fire, turning often, until charred and cooked through, about 10–12 minutes.
In a bowl, mix softened butter with chili powder, smoked paprika, cayenne, lime zest, lime juice, and salt.
Brush or spread the chili–lime butter over the hot roasted corn.
Serve immediately.
history: The book explains that roasted corn has deep roots in Indigenous American cuisine, long before European arrival. Southwestern and Mexican cooking later popularized pairing corn with chili and lime. This modern version reflects that heritage, combining fire-roasting techniques with a spiced butter inspired by Indigenous and Mexican flavor traditions. Street vendors across the Americas continue to sell grilled corn dressed with chili and citrus, showing the dish’s enduring appeal.

name: Atole (Mexican Corn Drink)
instructions: Whisk masa harina with 1 cup of cold milk or water until smooth.
Heat the remaining milk or water in a pot over medium heat.
Add the masa mixture, sugar, and cinnamon stick.
Simmer 10–12 minutes, whisking often, until thickened.
Remove the cinnamon stick and stir in vanilla.
Serve warm.
history: Atole is one of the oldest drinks in Mesoamerica, dating back to the Aztecs and Mayans. Made from nixtamalized corn dough or masa harina, it was consumed daily as nourishment and during ceremonies. The book explains that atole could be flavored with honey, chili, fruit, or cacao, depending on the region. After the Spanish arrived, ingredients like milk, sugar, and cinnamon were incorporated, creating the modern version still enjoyed across Mexico, especially during Día de los Muertos and winter festivals.

name: Calabaza en Tacha (Candied Pumpkin)
ingredients: 1 small pumpkin (such as sugar pumpkin), cut into wedges
2 cups (400 g) piloncillo or dark brown sugar
instructions: Cut pumpkin into wedges, leaving the skin on.
In a large pot, combine piloncillo, water, cinnamon stick, cloves, and orange peel.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer until the sugar dissolves.
Add the pumpkin wedges, arranging them snugly in the syrup.
Simmer uncovered for 60–90 minutes until the pumpkin is tender and the syrup thickens.
Turn pumpkin occasionally to glaze evenly.
Serve warm or at room temperature with extra syrup spooned over the top.
history: Calabaza en Tacha is a traditional Mexican dish served during Día de los Muertos. Its origins predate the Spanish conquest, when pumpkins were cooked with honey or maguey syrup. After the arrival of the Spanish, piloncillo, cinnamon, and cloves were added, blending Indigenous and European flavors. The dish is often prepared in clay pots called 'tachas,' giving the recipe its name. The book notes that it remains a common offering on altars during the Day of the Dead, symbolizing sweetness for returning spirits.

name: Churros (Spanish / Mexican)
instructions: Combine water, butter, sugar, and salt in a saucepan and bring to a boil.
Remove from heat and add flour all at once.
Stir vigorously until dough forms and pulls away from the sides.
Let dough cool slightly, then transfer to a piping bag fitted with a star tip.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C) in a deep pan.
Pipe 4–6 inch strips of dough into the hot oil, cutting with scissors.
Fry until golden brown, about 2–3 minutes per side.
Remove and drain on paper towels.
Roll warm churros in sugar or cinnamon sugar.
Serve immediately.
history: Churros likely originated with Spanish shepherds who cooked simple fried dough over open fires. Some culinary historians trace them to Chinese 'youtiao,' brought to Spain by Portuguese traders. In Spain, churros became a breakfast food served with thick drinking chocolate, while in Mexico they evolved into a sweeter version often coated in cinnamon sugar. The book notes that by the 19th century, churros were common street food throughout Spain and Latin America, with vendors specializing in fresh, hot fritters.

name: Chocolate (Mesoamerican Hot Chocolate)
ingredients: 3 ounces (85 g) cacao nibs or 100% cacao paste
1/2 teaspoon chili powder or a small piece of dried chili
instructions: Grind cacao nibs into a fine paste using a mortar and pestle or spice grinder.
Bring water to a simmer in a pot.
Whisk in the cacao paste until fully dissolved.
Add chili and optional cinnamon.
Simmer for 5 minutes, whisking vigorously to create foam.
Sweeten with honey or sugar if desired.
Pour from a height to increase froth and serve warm.
history: Mesoamerican chocolate was consumed for thousands of years before European contact. The Maya and Aztecs prepared chocolate as a frothy, bitter drink flavored with chili, vanilla, and flowers. It was considered sacred—used in religious ceremonies, royal banquets, and even as currency. The book notes that cacao was believed to be a divine gift from the god Quetzalcoatl. Unlike modern hot chocolate, the original beverage contained no milk and relied on vigorous pouring to produce its characteristic foam. The Spanish later introduced sugar, cinnamon, and milk, transforming it into the sweet drink known worldwide today.

name: Chocolate Atole (Champurrado)
ingredients: 3 ounces (85 g) Mexican chocolate or dark chocolate
instructions: Whisk masa harina with 1 cup of cold milk or water until smooth.
Heat the remaining milk or water in a pot with the cinnamon stick.
Add the masa mixture and whisk to avoid lumps.
Stir in chopped chocolate and sugar if using.
Simmer for 10–12 minutes, whisking often, until thick and smooth.
Remove cinnamon stick and serve warm.
history: Champurrado is a variation of atole enriched with chocolate, combining two ancient Mesoamerican traditions—corn-based drinks and ceremonial cacao beverages. The Aztecs and Maya consumed both separately, but the Spanish-era introduction of sugar and dairy led to the modern fusion. The book notes champurrado's strong ties to festivities such as Las Posadas, Day of the Dead, and Christmas, where it is served with tamales. Its thick, comforting texture comes from masa harina, making it more hearty than typical hot chocolate.

name: 18th-Century Oliebollen (Dutch Doughnuts)
instructions: Warm the milk and dissolve the yeast in it.
Mix flour, sugar, and salt in a bowl.
Add the yeast mixture and egg; stir to form a sticky dough.
Fold in raisins or currants.
Cover and let rise 1 hour until doubled in size.
Heat oil to 350°F (175°C).
Drop spoonfuls of dough into the hot oil.
Fry 3–4 minutes per side until golden brown.
Drain on paper towels.
Dust generously with powdered sugar before serving.
history: Oliebollen are traditional Dutch doughnuts eaten especially on New Year’s Eve. The book notes that the earliest versions appear in 17th-century Dutch paintings, where they were called 'oliekoeken' (oil cakes). By the 18th century, oliebollen had evolved into sweet, fruit-filled fried dough balls associated with winter festivals. Dutch immigrants later brought them to America, where they influenced the development of modern doughnuts. The raisins or currants were common additions that reflected winter pantry ingredients.

name: Wassail (Old English Hot Cider/Punch)
instructions: In a large pot, combine apple cider, ale, sherry (if using), and sugar.
Add cinnamon stick, cloves, grated nutmeg, and orange peel.
Bring to a gentle simmer over medium heat.
Place the cored apples into the pot and simmer until they begin to soften and split, about 15–20 minutes.
Remove apples if desired or leave them in for presentation.
Serve hot in mugs with a ladle of the spiced punch.
history: Wassail is an ancient English holiday drink associated with Yuletide and Twelfth Night celebrations. The term comes from the Old English 'wes hál,' meaning 'be healthy.' Historically, wassailing involved visiting orchards to bless apple trees for a good harvest or going door-to-door singing while receiving drinks. The book notes that medieval wassail was a hot mixture of cider or ale with spices and roasted apples, creating a frothy, warming punch. Over centuries, wassail evolved but remained tied to winter rituals, hospitality, and communal celebration.

name: Plum Duff (Sailor’s Steamed Pudding)
instructions: Mix flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar in a bowl.
Add raisins or currants and stir to coat them in the dry mixture.
Cut in suet or butter until the mixture resembles coarse crumbs.
Stir in water or milk to form a thick batter.
Grease a pudding basin or heatproof bowl and pour in the batter.
Cover tightly with cloth or foil.
Place basin in a pot with water halfway up the sides.
Cover pot and steam for 1.5 to 2 hours, checking water level occasionally.
Remove basin, cool briefly, then unmold and slice.
history: Plum duff was a staple dessert aboard British naval ships in the 18th and 19th centuries. Despite the name, it contains no plums—'plum' was a common term for raisins. Sailors eagerly awaited duff days, usually twice a week, as it was one of the few sweet dishes served at sea. The book notes that the recipe relied on ingredients that stored well on long voyages: flour, dried fruit, and suet. Steamed puddings like this became symbols of British naval life, often associated with camaraderie and rare comfort during harsh conditions.

name: Sago Plum Pudding (Victorian Era)
instructions: Soak sago in milk for 1 hour.
Heat mixture gently until sago becomes translucent and thickened.
Remove from heat and stir in sugar, salt, nutmeg, and melted butter.
Beat eggs and whisk them into the warm mixture.
Fold in raisins or currants.
Grease a pudding basin and pour in the mixture.
Cover with cloth or foil.
Place basin in a pot with water halfway up the sides.
Cover and steam for 1.5 to 2 hours.
Let cool slightly before unmolding and slicing.
history: Sago plum pudding was a Victorian spin on traditional Christmas pudding, using sago pearls—imported starch from tropical palms—in place of heavier suet and breadcrumbs. The book explains that Victorians saw sago dishes as both fashionable and digestible, fitting into the era’s obsession with 'healthy' puddings. Despite the name, like many 'plum' dishes of the time, it contains no plums—the word referred to raisins or any dried fruit. This pudding was popular in middle-class households that wanted a lighter alternative to the dense Christmas plum pudding.

name: Posset (Medieval / Tudor England)
ingredients: 1/4 cup (60 ml) ale, wine, or cider
instructions: Heat milk or cream in a pot until steaming but not boiling.
Whisk in sugar, nutmeg, and ginger.
Remove from heat.
Quickly pour in ale, wine, or cider while whisking.
Let sit a moment until the mixture thickens and lightly curdles.
Serve warm in cups.
history: Posset was a popular medieval and Tudor English drink made by curdling hot milk with ale, wine, or cider and flavoring it with spices. It was consumed both as a comforting winter beverage and as a medicinal remedy for colds, insomnia, and general weakness. The book notes that posset appears in Shakespeare’s works and was often served at celebrations, including weddings and feasts. By the 17th century, it evolved into more custard-like desserts, eventually inspiring the modern lemon posset.

name: Bourbon Punch (18th Century America)
ingredients: 1 cup (235 ml) strong black tea, cooled
instructions: Mix sugar with warm tea until dissolved.
Add bourbon, lemon juice, and cold water.
Stir well and chill before serving.
Garnish with lemon slices in the punch bowl or glasses.
history: Punch was one of the most popular beverages in colonial America. Originating from South Asian punch traditions brought through British trade, it typically included alcohol, citrus, tea, sugar, and water. The book notes that by the 18th century, American variations featured domestic spirits like bourbon. Served at taverns, political gatherings, and social events, bourbon punch became a symbol of hospitality. Founding Fathers such as Washington and Jefferson were known to enjoy similar punch recipes during large gatherings.

name: Barley Water
instructions: Rinse barley thoroughly under cold water.
Combine barley and water in a pot and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer 40–45 minutes until liquid becomes cloudy and slightly thickened.
Strain out and discard the barley (or save it for another use).
Sweeten with sugar or honey if desired.
Add lemon peel or lemon juice for flavor.
Serve warm or chilled.
history: Barley water is one of the oldest documented beverages in the world. The Greeks drank it as kykeon, the Romans as a restorative tonic, and medieval physicians prescribed it to soothe fevers, stomach ailments, and dehydration. The book notes that barley water appears in medical texts from Hippocrates to Tudor-era herbals. Its popularity persisted into the Victorian period as both a household remedy and a refreshing drink. Barley’s natural starches thicken the liquid slightly, giving it a nourishing, hydrating quality prized for centuries.

name: Bulgur Pilaf (Middle Eastern / Ottoman)
ingredients: 2 tablespoons (28 g) butter or olive oil
2 cups (475 ml) vegetable broth or water
instructions: Heat butter or olive oil in a pot over medium heat.
Add chopped onion and sauté until translucent.
Stir in bulgur and toast lightly for 1–2 minutes.
Pour in vegetable broth or water, then add salt and pepper.
Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low.
Cover and simmer 15–20 minutes until liquid is absorbed.
Remove from heat and rest 5 minutes before fluffing with a fork.
history: Bulgur has been a staple grain in the Middle East for thousands of years, originating in ancient Mesopotamia. The book notes that bulgur was valued by Ottoman cooks for its long shelf life and quick cooking time compared to whole wheat. Pilafs—grain dishes cooked with fat and broth—were central to Ottoman cuisine, eaten by both commoners and the elite. This simple bulgur pilaf reflects traditional Anatolian household cooking and continues to be a common side or main dish across Turkey and the Levant.

name: Mujaddara (Lentils & Rice with Fried Onions)
ingredients: 1 cup (200 g) brown or green lentils
instructions: Rinse lentils and place them in a pot with 2 cups of water.
Bring to a boil and simmer 15 minutes until halfway cooked.
Add rice, salt, pepper, and an additional cup of water or broth.
Cover and simmer 20 minutes until rice and lentils are tender.
Meanwhile, heat olive oil in a pan and fry sliced onions until deep golden brown.
Reserve some onions for garnish, and stir the rest into the cooked lentil–rice mixture.
Fluff and serve topped with remaining fried onions.
history: Mujaddara is a staple Levantine dish dating back to medieval Arab cuisine. The book notes that it appears in 13th-century manuscripts as a humble dish of lentils cooked with rice or bulgur, often eaten by the poor but enjoyed by all classes during fasting periods. In many Middle Eastern cultures, mujaddara is considered comfort food and is associated with simplicity, nourishment, and family meals. The iconic fried onions are a traditional topping that adds sweetness and richness.

name: Feteer (Egyptian Layered Pastry)
ingredients: 1/2 cup (115 g) butter or ghee, melted
instructions: Combine flour and salt in a bowl.
Gradually add warm water to form a soft dough.
Knead until smooth, then divide dough into 4 balls.
Coat dough balls generously in butter or ghee and let rest 30 minutes.
On a greased surface, stretch each ball into an extremely thin sheet.
Fold edges inward to form layered squares while brushing with more butter.
Repeat with remaining dough.
Heat a pan over medium heat and cook each folded pastry until golden brown on both sides.
Serve warm, plain or with honey, cheese, or sugar.
history: Feteer, also called feteer meshaltet, dates back to ancient Egypt, where early versions were offered to the gods. The book notes that its distinctive flaky layers come from stretching dough paper-thin and folding it repeatedly with ghee. Medieval Arab cookbooks describe similar layered pastries served at feasts. Today, feteer remains a beloved Egyptian dish—both savory and sweet—served to guests as a symbol of hospitality.

name: Torshi (Middle Eastern Pickled Vegetables)
ingredients: 1 cup (150 g) cucumbers or zucchini, chopped
instructions: Sterilize jars with boiling water and let them dry.
Pack chopped vegetables, garlic, and chilies into jars.
In a pot, combine vinegar, water, salt, and turmeric; bring to a boil.
Pour the hot pickling liquid over the vegetables, covering them completely.
Seal jars and let cool.
Refrigerate for several days before eating for best flavor.
history: Torshi (also spelled turshi or torsh) is a traditional Middle Eastern pickle with roots stretching back to ancient Persia and Mesopotamia. The book explains that pickling vegetables in vinegar and spices was essential for preserving food through winter. Versions of torshi appear across the Middle East—from Iran’s turmeric-heavy pickles to Lebanon’s bright pink turnip pickles colored with beet. Torshi remains a staple side dish served with rice, stews, kebabs, and mezze.

name: Mast-o-Khiar (Persian Yogurt & Cucumber Dip)
instructions: Combine yogurt and chopped cucumber in a bowl.
Stir in dried mint, raisins, walnuts, and salt.
Mix until well combined.
Chill before serving for best flavor.
history: Mast-o-khiar is a classic Persian side dish that dates back to ancient Iranian cuisine. The book explains that yogurt (mast) has been a staple in Persia for millennia, prized for its cooling and digestive qualities. Cucumber and mint were common additions in medieval Persian cooking, and the combination appears in multiple historical manuscripts. Traditionally served alongside rice dishes and kebabs, mast-o-khiar symbolizes hospitality and remains an essential part of modern Iranian meals and mezze spreads.

name: Qatayef (Middle Eastern Stuffed Pancakes)
ingredients: 1 cup (150 g) crushed nuts (walnuts or pistachios)
instructions: Mix flour, warm water, sugar, yeast, and baking powder to form a smooth batter.
Let batter rest 30 minutes until bubbly.
Heat a skillet over medium heat.
Pour small rounds of batter and cook only on one side until bubbles form and surface dries.
Remove pancakes and keep covered under a towel.
Mix crushed nuts with sugar and cinnamon for the filling.
Place a spoonful of nut filling in each pancake, fold in half, and pinch edges to seal.
Option 1: Fry stuffed qatayef in a little butter or oil until golden.
Option 2: Bake at 375°F (190°C) for 10–12 minutes.
Drizzle with simple syrup before serving.
history: Qatayef is a traditional Arab dessert associated mainly with Ramadan. The book notes that it dates back to at least the Abbasid Caliphate, where early versions appear in medieval cookbooks. Historically, qatayef sellers filled the streets during Ramadan evenings, serving pancakes stuffed with nuts, cheese, or cream. The method of cooking them only on one side is characteristic and mentioned in several medieval culinary texts. Today, qatayef remains one of the most beloved Ramadan desserts across the Middle East.

name: Mahshi (Stuffed Vegetables)
ingredients: 6–8 zucchini or bell peppers (or a mix of vegetables)
1 cup (235 ml) vegetable broth or water
instructions: Core or hollow out zucchini, peppers, or other vegetables you are using.
Rinse rice and combine with onion, tomato, parsley, olive oil, salt, pepper, cinnamon, and allspice.
Stuff vegetables loosely, leaving space for rice to expand.
Arrange stuffed vegetables in a pot.
Pour vegetable broth or water over them until halfway up the sides.
Place a heatproof plate on top to keep them from floating.
Cover and simmer 45–60 minutes until vegetables are tender and rice is cooked.
Serve warm.
history: Mahshi—meaning 'stuffed' in Arabic—has origins in the Ottoman Empire, where stuffed vegetables and leaves were widespread across the region. The book highlights that Egyptian and Levantine versions traditionally use rice, vegetables, herbs, and mild spices. Historically, mahshi was a celebratory dish served at family gatherings and feasts, and each region developed its own variations. In Egypt, zucchini and peppers are common, while Levantine traditions also include stuffing eggplants, onions, and even potatoes.

name: Ful Medames (Egyptian Stewed Fava Beans)
instructions: Rinse dried fava beans and soak overnight.
Drain and place in a pot with fresh water.
Simmer 45–60 minutes until beans are very soft.
Mash lightly with a spoon.
Add salt, olive oil, lemon juice, garlic, and cumin.
Simmer 5 more minutes to blend flavors.
Serve warm with bread or toppings like chopped parsley or tomatoes.
history: Ful medames is one of Egypt’s oldest dishes, tracing its origins back to Pharaonic times. The book notes that medieval Cairo used large communal cauldrons that simmered fava beans overnight to feed the city at dawn. Ful became the national breakfast of Egypt, valued for its affordability, nourishment, and long history. It appears in medieval Arab cookbooks and remains a staple across the Middle East today.

name: Hummus (Levantine Chickpea Dip)
instructions: Soak chickpeas overnight with baking soda.
Drain and simmer in fresh water 40–60 minutes until very soft.
Drain and let cool slightly.
Blend chickpeas with tahini, garlic, lemon juice, salt, and cold water until smooth and creamy.
Serve with olive oil drizzled on top.
history: Hummus has deep roots in Levantine cuisine, though its precise origin is debated among Lebanon, Palestine, Syria, and Israel. The book notes that early medieval Arab cookbooks contain recipes for pureed chickpeas with tahini, vinegar, and herbs—clear ancestors of modern hummus. It became a staple of mezze spreads throughout the Middle East and later gained global popularity for its flavor and nutritional value. Traditional hummus is characterized by its silky texture and balance of nutty tahini and bright lemon.

name: Halvah (Middle Eastern Sesame Sweet)
instructions: Heat sugar and water in a saucepan over medium heat.
Simmer until mixture reaches soft-ball stage (235°F / 113°C).
Remove from heat and stir in vanilla or rosewater.
Quickly fold in tahini until mixture thickens and begins to seize.
Stir in pistachios if using.
Pour into a parchment-lined dish and press flat.
Cool completely before slicing.
history: Halvah has ancient roots in Persia and the Middle East, where sesame and sugar-based sweets were common in medieval kitchens. The book notes that halva spread west through the Ottoman Empire and became a staple confection across Turkey, the Levant, and North Africa. Traditional halvah varies by region—some are flour-based, while sesame halvah (tahini halva) is especially popular in the Arab world. Its crumbly texture and rich sesame flavor made it a favored treat for festivals and religious holidays.

name: Chai (Indian Spiced Tea)
instructions: Bring water, ginger, cardamom, and optional spices to a boil.
Add loose tea and simmer briefly.
Add milk and sugar.
Bring back to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer 1–2 minutes.
Strain into cups and serve hot.
history: Chai, meaning simply 'tea' in Hindi, developed into its spiced form during British colonial rule, when India became one of the world's largest tea producers. The book notes that while tea drinking was introduced by the British, Indians adapted it by adding milk, sugar, and regional spices such as ginger, cardamom, cloves, and cinnamon. By the early 20th century, masala chai had become a national beverage sold by roadside vendors (chaiwalas) and enjoyed daily across the country.

name: Chicken Salad (Ancient Roman)
ingredients: 200 ml posca (100 ml water + 100 ml white wine)
instructions: Grate the Parmesan cheese.
Cook the chicken livers by frying them in a little olive oil, then cool and chop them into small pieces.
Peel and slice the cucumber thinly.
Drain and chop the capers finely.
Cut the ciabatta into thin slices and lay them out on a large tray.
Dribble the posca over the slices and allow the liquid to be absorbed by the bread.
Get a medium sized bowl for the dressing.
Roast the celery seed, then grind it and mix with black pepper and mint.
Grind the mint and pine kernels together into a fine paste, then add in the fish sauce and vinegar.
Stir in the soft cheese, honey, and egg yolks.
Gradually add in the water and blend ingredients together.
Gently squeeze the liquid out of the bread slices and lay them on a large plate.
Add the salad mixture on each bread slice, then a layer of cucumbers.
Add the dressing on top of the salad and bread.
Refrigerate for 2 hours before serving for best results.
Serve and enjoy!
history: This salad reflects the wealthy dining habits of the late Roman Republic and early Empire. Chicken liver was considered a delicacy, often served at elaborate banquets. The use of posca—diluted sour wine—shows how Romans repurposed everyday soldiers’ drink in creative ways for cooking. Mint, honey, and fish sauce (garum) were essential to Roman flavor profiles, blending sweet, salty, and herbal notes. Bread soaked in wine-based liquids was a common way to stretch ingredients and create layered textures. Similar preparations appear in Apicius, the oldest surviving Roman cookbook.

name: Cheese and Fruit Dip (Ancient Roman)
instructions: Get a medium sized bowl to put ingredients in.
Roast and then grind the lovage, then mix with pepper and add in the mint.
Add the raisins and grind into fine paste.
Next add the pine kernels and continue to make a paste.
Add the cheese, date syrup, and honey. Blend well.
Gradually add the fish sauce, vinegar, olive oil, grape juice, and wine.
Blend well.
Serve in a dish for dipping.
Serve with hard bread, vegetables such as cucumber or carrot sticks, cold meats, cooked prawns, or cooked fish pieces.
history: This dip is characteristic of Roman fondness for combining sweet fruits, nuts, herbs, and cheese. Lovage, mint, and pepper were widely grown in Roman gardens, described by writers like Pliny and Columella. Romans enjoyed fruit-based relishes and spreads, often flavored with wine and honey. Date syrup (defrutum) was extremely common, produced by boiling fruit juice into a thick reduction. This kind of dip would have appeared as a starter (gustatio) at a Roman convivium, served with bread, vegetables, and seafood.

name: Roast Chicken in Honey and Dill (Ancient Roman)
instructions: Dry roast the dill seed and grind into fine powder.
Chop the mint and add with the ground dill.
Add and stir all the sauce ingredients into a bowl, mixing well.
Mix together the sauce, honey, and fish sauce, then set aside.
Parboil the chicken for a maximum of 45 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 375°F / 190°C / Gas mark 5.
Drain the chicken from the water and wipe away excess moisture.
Put the chicken into a roasting pan and score the legs and breast about half an inch deep.
Pour the prepared sauce mixture onto the chicken, ensuring the cuts absorb the sauce.
Put the chicken into the oven for 30 minutes to an hour, until the sauce runs clear.
Baste the chicken every 10 minutes. Add a little water if the sauce becomes too thick.
When fully cooked, serve and enjoy.
history: Romans frequently cooked poultry with a combination of herbs, honey, vinegar, and garum (fish sauce). Honey-glazed meats appear repeatedly in Apicius, showcasing the Roman love for sweet-and-sour flavors. Dill and mint were widely cultivated in kitchen gardens and noted for their medicinal qualities. The method of parboiling before roasting was common in Roman kitchens, making meat tender while absorbing marinades more effectively. This dish would have been served as part of a multi-course feast to impress guests with rich aromas and glossy presentation.

name: Lamb in Date Sauce (Ancient Roman)
ingredients: 300 ml goat, sheep, or cow milk
instructions: Get the butcher to bone the shoulder.
Drizzle a little fish sauce inside the meat and bind it up into a neat roll with kitchen string.
Place the vegetables in a roasting dish, then place the lamb on top.
Cover with tin foil and roast slowly at 350°F / 180°C / Gas 4 for at least 3 hours.
Remove the foil for the last hour and increase the heat slightly.
Remove the meat and vegetables and set aside while the sauce is finished.
Retain all juices from the dish and drain off the fat.
Make the sauce by combining the juices with dates, fish sauce, olive oil, and white wine.
Thicken the sauce with cornflour.
Serve the lamb with the date sauce.
history: Lamb was a prized meat in the Roman Empire, especially for feasts and religious celebrations. Dates were imported across the Mediterranean, particularly from North Africa and the Near East, making them a luxurious addition to elite Roman dishes. The combination of lamb, dates, and wine reflects Rome’s love for sweet-savoury contrasts, a signature of ancient gastronomy. Fish sauce was universally used, even in meat dishes, as a salt and umami source. Slow-roasting with vegetables mirrors Roman domestic cooking practices, where meats were often cooked for long periods in clay ovens.

name: Harappan Proto-Curry (World’s Oldest Known Curry)
ingredients: 1 fresh turmeric root, ground (or 1/4 tsp turmeric powder)
1 tbsp raw mango, cut into cubes
Dehydrated sugarcane juice to taste (jaggery as replacement)
A few leaves of sweet basil (optional)
instructions: Wet grind the ginger, turmeric, and cumin seeds into a paste.
Heat sesame oil in an earthen pot (or pan).
Add the spice paste and cook for a couple of minutes until aromatic.
Tip in the slit aubergines, add salt, and stir well.
Cover and cook until the aubergines are nearly done. Add a little water if required.
Stir in the raw mango cubes and dehydrated sugarcane juice.
Simmer for a few minutes until the mango softens.
Check seasoning and adjust salt or sweetness.
Serve hot with bajra roti (pearl millet flatbread), as the Harappans likely did.
history: This dish is based on the world's oldest known curry identified at the Harappan excavation site of Farmana near modern-day Delhi. Archaeologists Arunima Kashyap and Steve Webber used starch grain analysis on pottery shards, stone tools, and even the dental enamel of ancient humans and livestock to identify molecular traces of turmeric, ginger, aubergine (eggplant), mango, bananas, dates, and gourds. Their findings proved that Harappans cooked a proto-curry over 4,000 years ago, long before the word 'curry' existed. The humble Harappan curry shows deep continuity in Indian cooking practices: ginger (adraka), turmeric (haridra), and aubergine (vrntaka) are all native to the region, with names that predate Sanskrit and have roots in Munda languages. The recipe above is a faithful reconstruction using ingredients known to be present in the era, cooked in earthen pots. It highlights how everyday Harappans lived, ate, and preserved culinary traditions that survive in Indian kitchens today.
